page.title: 03Airships of the Past
page.content:
An airship is an enornous balloon filled with a gas lighter than air. It is fitted with engines and steered by rudders. The crew guide the craft from a gondola under the main frame. When airships were first built they were thought to be the only possible means of flying for passengers.
The R101 which was built at Cardington was 777 feet long and weighed about 167 tons. It was made of steel and filled with hydrogen a very dangerous gas. It crashed in Beauvais France on October 5th 1930 whilst attempting to fly to India. All but a few were lost. This was the last British effort to fly large airships.
